title: Clean Code
author: Robert C. Martin
review: The handbook for craftsmanship. It taught me that writing code is like writing a story—it should be elegant, readable, and easy to maintain for the next person who visits the campsite.

title: Habluder Jonno Programming
author: Jhankar Mahbub
review: The best entry point for any Bengali speaker into the world of logic. It breaks down complex computer science concepts into hilarious, relatable metaphors that stay with you forever.

title: Programming-er Bolod to Bos
author: Jhankar Mahbub
review: The sequel that bridges the gap between a beginner and a professional. It focuses on the mindset of a developer, teaching you how to solve problems like a 'Boss' rather than just typing code.

title: Laws of UX
author: Jon Yablonski
review: A masterclass in psychology for designers. Understanding how users perceive and interact with digital interfaces is the secret sauce to building products that feel natural and intuitive.

title: Designing Interfaces
author: Jenifer Tidwell
review: A comprehensive pattern library for UI. It provides a deep dive into successful interaction design strategies, helping me understand why certain layouts work while others fail.

title: 100 Things Every Designer Needs to Know About People
author: Susan M. Weinschenk
review: Designing without understanding psychology is just decoration. This book explains the way people think, see, and remember, which is crucial for creating effective user experiences.

title: The Elements of User Experience
author: Jesse James Garrett
review: The foundation of modern UX design. Garrett’s five planes—Strategy, Scope, Structure, Skeleton, and Surface—gave me a clear framework for building products from the ground up.

title: The Design of Everyday Things
author: Don Norman
review: The ultimate book on cognitive engineering. It taught me that if a user can't figure out how to use a door or an app, it's the design's fault, not the user's. A life-changing perspective.

title: Refactoring UI
author: Adam Wathan & Steve Schoger
review: The practical guide that every developer needs. It moves away from abstract art and provides tactical, actionable advice to make any application look polished and professional.

title: The 48 Laws of Power
author: Robert Greene
review: A brutal and brilliant study of human nature and social dynamics. While controversial, it provides indispensable insights into the power structures of the professional and social world.

title: Sherlock Holmes
author: Sir Arthur Conan Doyle
review: The pinnacle of deductive reasoning. Sherlock’s ability to see what others only observe is a skill I try to apply when debugging complex codebases or analyzing user data.

title: Feluda
author: Satyajit Ray
review: The quintessential Bengali detective. Ray’s storytelling and Prodosh Chandra Mitter’s 'Magajastro' (brain-weapon) are a testament to the power of observation and sharp intellect.

title: Byomkesh Bakshi
author: Sharadindu Bandyopadhyay
review: More than just a detective, he is a 'Satyanweshi' (seeker of truth). The intricate plots and historical context make these stories a masterclass in narrative logic and human psychology.

title: Kakababu
author: Sunil Gangopadhyay
review: Raja Roychowdhury’s adventures combine archaeology, history, and mystery. They taught me that curiosity and courage are the most important tools for any explorer or engineer.

title: Arjun Kumar
author: Samaresh Majumdar
review: A unique detective series featuring a young, agile seeker of truth. It’s a refreshing take on the genre that emphasizes movement, modern settings, and relentless pursuit.

title: Pragmatic Programmer
author: Andrew Hunt
review: Changed how I approach problems. 'Don't Repeat Yourself' is my mantra now.

title: Atomic Habits
author: James Clear
review: Small improvements compound into massive changes. Applied this to my coding practice.

title: Zero to One
author: Peter Thiel
review: Vertical progress vs Horizontal progress. Essential for startup thinking.
